name: Lithium Orotate
summary: Lithium orotate is a dietary supplement form of lithium, sometimes promoted for mood stabilization, anxiety, and neuroprotection, though clinical evidence is limited.
description: Lithium orotate is a salt of lithium and orotic acid, available as an over-the-counter dietary supplement. Unlike prescription lithium carbonate or citrate, which are FDA-approved for bipolar disorder and mood stabilization, lithium orotate has not been approved for any psychiatric condition. Advocates claim it may deliver lithium more efficiently at lower doses, but this has not been conclusively demonstrated. Some preliminary evidence and case reports suggest potential benefits for mood stabilization, impulse control, and neuroprotection. However, safety concerns remain, as lithium—even at low doses—can accumulate and affect kidney and thyroid function.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for psychiatric treatment)

monitoring_required: Serum lithium levels (if used long-term or at high doses)

sections.text: Lithium orotate, like other lithium salts, is thought to act via inhibition of glycogen synthase kinase-3 (GSK-3), modulation of second messenger systems (IP3, cAMP), and enhancement of neurotrophic factors such as BDNF. At low supplemental doses, the degree of CNS penetration and efficacy compared to prescription lithium is not well established.

adult.typical: 5–20 mg elemental lithium daily (from lithium orotate)
adult.range: Up to 120 mg elemental lithium daily in some reports, though safety at higher doses is unclear

sections.text: May require weeks of consistent use for mood effects; neuroprotective benefits are theoretical and long-term.

other: Risk of lithium accumulation with long-term use
Avoid use in patients on concurrent lithium carbonate or citrate therapy
Pregnancy category D (based on prescription lithium data)

items.action: Monitor renal function and lithium levels

sections.pregnancy: Avoid; prescription lithium linked to fetal risk
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; not recommended
sections.geriatrics: Increased risk of lithium accumulation; avoid unless medically supervised

sections.text: No formal tapering required at supplemental doses, but sudden discontinuation in those using it for mood stabilization may cause symptom relapse.

items: Lithium orotate is sometimes used in ‘microdosing lithium’ approaches for mood and cognitive support.
Serum lithium levels from supplementation are typically much lower than therapeutic levels in prescription use, but safety data are sparse.
Caution is warranted, as lithium has a narrow therapeutic index even at low doses.
